query: What did Barry Hughes think about the law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought the law should reflect contemporary society and the law was evolutionary in nature. There was a spectrum of offending. At one end, it was relatively white and the other end was relatively black, but in the middle there were multiple shades of grey. The police would take a view that the evidential test may have been satisfied because the defence had been removed, but it wouldn't be in the public interest to prosecute.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the bill to remove a defence for light smacking on the leg when talking about the application of the legislation in Wales?
summary: Barry Hughes explained that the bill would remove a defence, which would make it likely that the police would give this more consideration for referral to the CPS than beforehand, but it didn't necessarily mean they would refer it, because it would depend on the facts of each individual case. In terms of how they would approach it within the Crown Prosecution Service in Cymru-Wales, his approach would be along the lines of working with Kwame and his colleagues to make sure that the guidance that they issue nationally suits both England and Wales. And when it comes to the practical application of the legislation in Wales, they would almost certainly work on the basis that the number of offences would be very small and they would probably have two or three specialists trained in this so that any case that came through would go to people who had got a close network and would talk with each other.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the guidance on the divergence of criminal law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought they would need to update the guidance, and it went back to the application of the evidential stage, before the public interest stage. They might have some light-touch guidance around that. When it came to public interest, that's a little more specialist and they needed to develop more with respect to that.

query: What did the group discuss about the public interest test?
summary: Suzy Davies thought the public interest test was critical in all this, and it would really help them to understand what it could look like before they commit to a particular course of action in supporting or not supporting the Bill. However, Barry Hughes did not think that would necessarily be helpful. What they would envisage was that they would simply want to take the present public interest factors, which were set out, in my view, very clearly in the code for Crown prosecutors, and they would provide a degree of detail around those that relates more specifically to the issues that they were discussing here. And they would need to work that up as they went along, and

query: What did Sian Gwenllian AM think about the criminal law in Wales and England diverging in this particular instance?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked Barry Hughes if there were other offences in Wales that didn't exist in England, but they didn't crop up very often. Barry Hughes answered that there were some, but the fact that you drive across the border into Scotland and commit an offence that you won't commit in England was possibly more significant for the general public. So, if they remove the defence of reasonable chastisement, in a sense that alters some things but it didn't alter the basic responsibility of the prosecution, which was to establish its case beyond a reasonable doubt.

query: What did Barry Hughes say about what might be done to prevent cases even coming as far as arrest?
summary: From the perspective of the CPS, I'm not sure I can help you there. We can't direct the police. It's a matter for the police, and we have got to disprove that to the criminal standard, which is beyond a reasonable doubt. I can see the potential for individuals who feel strongly about this to look to contest the matter, to not admit any wrongdoing at all and to take the matter to trial, and it would be our responsibility to prove that there had been an unlawful assault.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about keeping a clear record of cases referred to the CPS from the police?
summary: Suzy Davies AM thought that one of the difficulties of dealing with the culture change, which was what the Minister's effectively after here, was that they were still talking about it in the context of criminal legislation. Therefore, they would need to maintain a clear record of any cases that were referred to the CPS from the police and that they would keep a manual log of every referral. However, Barry Hughes thought that the numbers would be very small, which means they would be able to keep a clear track on those and they would wish to keep the situation under review, and they'd reach a period of time after whatever—12, 18 months, maybe 24 months—where they would look back to see how they were doing.

query: What were the factors that the CPS would be taking into consideration when applying the public interest test in respect of prosecutions?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, the essence of the public interest test was about proportionality, and trying to come up with an approach that was proportionate to the offending. Some of them were fairly obvious, such as previous convictions. If someone's got previous convictions for doing something wrong, it's more likely they're going to be prosecuted the next time. But there's no part of the law that says that prosecution will always follow.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the rights of the child when talking about out-of-court disposals?
summary: Barry Hughes explained that if there were an assault by someone else upon a child, outside the family, they would tend to take views from the parents of that child. In circumstances where both parents, arguably were the suspects, they probably wouldn't be asking them. They would find another way, and they would talk with the police to ensure that they were informed about how the child felt about what had happened. There was a body of law that said a child can't consent to assault. When it comes to much lesser assaults, the law was more unclear as to what you can consent to. It would need to be developed.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the duty to raise awareness of the unintended consequences?
summary: Vikki Howells AM asked about whether there should be a duty on the Government to raise awareness of the change. Barry Hughes answered that it was not for him to say whether there was a duty or not. He thought the greater the level of awareness, the more likely it was that the Act, if passed, would achieve its intentions. He also pointed out that if someone came to this country and committed an offence that was not an offence in their country, but was an offence here, then ignorance of the law was no defence.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the unintended consequence of the new law?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked if there was an unintended consequence of the new law, or the proposed law, would one unintended consequence be that, if someone living in Wales who can't use the reasonable punishment defence would be different compared to those people in England, who will be able to use that defence? Barry Hughes answered that it was extremely unlikely. It was not something that would cause concern, simply because they already had a well-developed approach to dealing with the way in which they evaluated the evidence from parties who may well have a particular position that they wanted to reinforce, sometimes through exaggeration of basic facts and sometimes through fabrication.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the lack of prosecutions when talking about the potential barriers to implementing the proposed law?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there is a huge body of legislation out there that outlaws certain offences, and they probably prosecute 5 per cent of those in any given year. However, the fact that they might not have many prosecutions is, for him, not a reason not to signify that certain behaviour is or is not acceptable. The criminal law provides a general framework within which to operate, which most people tend to understand. It may well be tested by case law; that's the way it's likely to happen.

query: What did PhD A think about speech enhancement?

query: What did the professor think about the well-matched condition?

query: What did the professor think about improving SNR?
summary: The professor thought that combining two techniques, spectral subtraction and Wiener filtering, could improve SNR, but it would not work very well with the poor SNR conditions and in colored noise. He suggested that they could try combining the techniques on the distant mike using the SRI recognizer.

query: What did the Professor think about voice discrimination?

The professor thought that the difference between the filter bank and the FFT was interesting and suggested that they should figure out if there was something in the difference which was useful. He also suggested that the model could be improved by using a neural network.

query: What’s the current status of transcription?

query: What did the team discuss about the belief-net?
summary: The team discussed the basic features of the belief-net and how they could incorporate them into the model. query: What did the professor think about the intermediate nodes?
summary: The professor thought that the ontology and discourse nodes should be included in the belief-net. The ontology nodes should have properties and the properties are filled in from ontology items. The discourse nodes would have properties that could contribute to whether a person wants to enter, view, or approach a given segment of the belief net. In the case of the endpoint endpoint, the properties would be key properties like whether the endpoint is a tourist site, a landmark, a place of business, etc.

query: What did the professor think about the entity type?
summary: The professor thought that the entity type should be a vector of several possible things, such as a landmark and a landmark at the same time as doing these things. The properties would fit into the decision node and the properties would be set based on the outer controlling conditioning of the entity. The professor also suggested that the endpoint decisions should be more than endpoint decisions, and they could merge them.

query: What did the Professor think about the user model?
summary: The professor thought that the model should be regarded as a vector of several possible things, such as selling things, fixing things, service things, exhibiting things, and being a landmark at the same time as doing these things. The model could also be used for multiple decisions. The professor also wanted to get rid of the long link between who the user is and the endpoint. This would allow the model to be more compact.

query: What did the professor think about the user model?

He suggested that they could pull various kinds of properties from the ontology like exhibiting, selling, and so forth to help them determine whether the user was compatible with something. He also suggested that the discourse could be used for multiple decisions.

query: What did the professor think about the Go-there and the Endpoint nodes?

query: What did the Professor think about Spanish and Italian?

query: What did PhD D think about the on-line normalization?

query: What did PhD D think about the phonetic categories?

The nets were trained on a well-controlled condition and were adding noise after training. query: What did PhD D think about LDA filters?
summary: PhD D thought that the LDA filter would not work alone because it would reduce the amount of information. However, the professor thought that they could include silence as an additional feature because the nets were trained on a well-controlled condition. The professor also mentioned that the median filter was enforcing that it would not be single cases of frames, or isolated frames.

query: What did the professor think about the team's discussion about capturing silence?
summary: The professor thought that the team was trying to figure out how they were going to get around the way the recognizer works because they were not allowed to change the scripts. He thought that they were throwing out chunks of frames, but the median filter was enforcing that it was not going to be single cases of frames. He also thought that it would be a good idea to detect silence because it would cut the number of bits that had to transmit a lot.

query: Summarize the discussion about the important findings of the previous discussion.
summary: The team agreed that innovation was more important than ease of use for the target group and the feel of the material had to be spongy. They also agreed that colouring was important and soft materials were even more important. They could make a round an oval remote control in yellow and a traditional one in grey and yellow. The team also agreed to make the remote control with an exchangeable cover.

query: What did Industrial Designer introduce about the casing and energy sources of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer introduced that the remote control would have three different casing possibilities, including an uncurved or flat case, a curved one, and an even more advanced shape, which is curved in three dimensions. In terms of the material of the casing, there would be different types of finishing, including plastic, rubber, wood, titanium, and latex. In addition, the team would have solar power and hand dynamos for powering the remote controls.

query: What did the group discuss about the power source of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the push-buttons and scroll-wheels could be integrated with buttons, while the traditional solar power would be used to transmit light energy into electricity. The group also discussed the possibility of integrating a scroll-bar on this side. However, the user interface designer thought that it would not be a good idea since it would be hard to integrate the scroll-wheel on a display. Also, the group decided that the voice recognition feature would consume quite a lot of power.

query: What did the group discuss about the casing material of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the market would like a sort of titanium casing, but they seemed to like natural stuff. Therefore, the group decided to skip the titanium stuff and use wood or something like that. The group also decided to use a regular chip instead of the advanced version, which was a bit more costly.

query: What did the group discuss about the appearance of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought it would be hard to print a picture on the remote control because the manufacturing department was not so advanced in its techniques. Project Manager thought LCD was not very flashy and new, so they should use the company colours. User Interface preferred the scroll-wheel and the additional buttons, which were spongy and rubber.

query: What did the group discuss about the functional design of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought it would be nice to print a picture on the remote control, but it would not be possible because their manufacturing department was not so advanced in its techniques and they were actually very slow in their techniques. However, the group agreed to use a scroll-wheel, scroll-heel and some additional buttons on which the buttons are not have to be rubber. The group also decided to use plastic buttons instead of rubber because the customers specifically asked for the spongy feel, and that's what they got with rubber.

query: What did employers think of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: According to Dr Rachel Bowen, most employers in Wales are small or microbusinesses. And while there are lots of small engaged employers who have taken an interest and do understand, the vast majority are more focused on getting on with the day-to-day running of the business. They certainly don't mention the Welsh baccalaureate and are very much questioning the qualifications that have been provided to develop the actual professional skills needed within the industries.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think of improving employers' understanding of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Dafydd Evans suggested that they need to review the qualification, and the voice of employers should be a key part of that review, so that employability skills and entrepreneurial skills have more of a role within the qualification. The aim of the baccalaureate was an excellent one, but they had lost their way in terms of what they did present at the end of the day, and having more input from employers would be a great help. And the only way they would get employer buy-in was if they felt ownership of what was being done.

query: Summarize the discussion about how well the Welsh baccalaureate helps to prepare learners for employment.
summary: The Welsh baccalaureate is a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification. It's a valid priority for the Welsh Government for everyone to get a C grade in the core subjects, and it's become very much focused on outcomes rather than necessarily skills. But that eats into the time that we have to teach young people. The Welsh bac, where it works really well, does help prepare them, I think, for employment, but it is not for everyone, because some people have to do the other things. So, it needs to be reviewed, to look at how we could make skilled and employable people.

query: What did the group discuss about the different levels of the Welsh baccalaureate valued by further education professionals?
summary: The Welsh baccalaureate was not a crowd puller in colleges, but at level 3 it was more, especially for A-levels, because it helped the more able and talented learners get into university. At level 1 and level 2, it was not what they would call a crowd-puller because it wasn't adopted by every admissions tutor in every university. So, to get into some areas, like dentistry, for example, and some of the other Seren-type activities, four A-Levels was better. But in most colleges that have A-level students it's almost compulsory to do the Welsh bac as well.

query: What did Kay Martin think of the extent do universities in the main understand the value of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Kay Martin did not think that universities in the main understand the value of the Welsh baccalaureate, especially the experience they had with some of their learners to go to Russell Group universities. Kay Martin thought it was mixed, and it did depend on the admissions tutors and the areas that they were going into in universities. A great number of our learners get into Cardiff using the baccalaurate, but some of the universities are not valuing it. So, they do, especially now it's graded at level 3. Then they do accept it. They do allow sometimes that you can drop a grade. But it's questionable, certainly at national and foundation.

query: What did Julie Morgan and Dafydd Evans discuss about the admission problems of Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: According to Julie Morgan, the admissions tutors throughout a lot of universities would make different decisions, and also make the decision dependent on whether it's a facilitating subject or an enabling subject, which the Russell Group report indicates about facilitating subjects, and Welsh baccalaureate at the moment is not a facilitating matter. Also, as Kay said, Welsh universities were much more willing to recognise the baccalureate, so it was less of a problem. But, naturally, they do have students who were looking to go out to universities in England in the Russell group, and they were having the same experience there where there were differences between the policy that that university extols and what actually happens on the ground when students had interviews in those universities. Therefore, they need to consider that.

query: What is the view of the Welsh baccalaureate as being rigorous?
summary: According to Kay Martin, it probably depends on the subjects that people are studying and the combination of subjects and the institution. Some learners in departments where they have really worked hard to contextualise the Welsh baccalaureate within the vocational area, within the A-level subjects that the learners are doing, are finding it very rewarding. They are more able and talented vocational learners who have the skills to look to teachers not as sources of information but just for guidance. The chances are that they've lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification. However, it is comparable as long as it achieves the right outcome for that particular learner.

query: What did the group say about the baccalaureate as a recruitment tool?
summary: The baccalaureate was best at producing independent, inquiry-based learners who had the skills to look to teachers not as sources of information but just for guidance. The chances were that they had lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification. In the majority of colleges across Wales, it was absolutely not used as a recruitment tool, because most of them, as you see, they value the Welsh bac. So, they wouldn't deliberately tell people, "Come on in and you won't have to do it."

query: What did Dafydd Evans think about the baccalaureate?
summary: Dafydd Evans believed that the baccalaureate was an integral part of the curriculum, and it was not an option for the student to opt out. It was part of what the college's curriculum offered—there was no doubt about that—and then people made a choice according to what they needed to do to actually progress to the next step. It came back to that fact that they were just making the assumption all learners were getting all the correct advice and guidance from all the institutions. If it was the right choice and if the Welsh bac was the correct choice, that was correct, and they move that along.

query: Summarize the discussion about the softer skills.
summary: According to Nick Brazil, they offer a range in the curriculum. The qualifications are well catered for. There's a big range, and some really high achievers coming into the sector as well. They are not going out there saying, 'Come to us for this particular reason.' They make the decision in the best interests of the learner. They do want to know that, and it's usually the first question that people always ask. So, for me, now, it's not a case of squeezing things out.

query: What did Sian Gwenllian AM think of the perception that parents have of the benefits for the pupil in their institution?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM suggested that it could be a short-sighted view because what some young people tell us is that at the time they didn't really appreciate what skills they were actually learning, and when they got into employment, that working as a team, the communication skills, they thought, 'Ah, we did—. I know what this is about', and it all made sense at that point. So, to try and sort of discourage it at a younger age may be doing them a disservice in the long run.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think of introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that training was required regarding the Welsh baccalaureate, but where they are seeing it more successfully is where vocational lecturers have actually taken it on board. When they were bringing lecturers from outside, it was not working well. It has started to work well when our sports lecturers had taken the Wales bac on board and have put it in the context of the sports curriculum. Therefore, no, he thought that if it was going to be a success, it's got to be contextualised, and they had invested heavily in training those vocational

query: What did Kirsty say about the feedback on the curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, there was a concerted effort and a plan drawn up to try and ensure that there was as much engagement, knowledge and opportunity as possible. So, they would make a statutory provision for the 'what matters' statements. They would also be looking to include in the legislation provision for a statutory framework setting out their approach to progression in each of the AoLE areas. And obviously they work very hard on making it as easy as possible via new technology for people to have their say.

query: What did Kirsty say about the purposes of the legislation?
summary: According to Kirsty, the four purposes would be set out in the legislation, and below the areas of learning and experience were the broad concepts that they would expect to be delivered in each of the AoLE areas. Then, below that, they were going to legislate for a number of the cross-curricular aspects—so, the literacy, the numeracy and the digital competency—as well as some elements where they had already said that they was going to make that statutory, so, for instance, above and beyond what Graham Donaldson would have put in his original reports. The 'what matters' were the articulation of the big ideas. They were always intended to represent, as a whole, the learning that every learner should get.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the response to the White Paper and the consultation on religious education and relationships and sexuality education?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that they had demonstrated that they were listening to people, that there had been concern expressed about certainty and having a national approach on some of these issues, and they had taken steps to address that and they would continue to reflect with their partners who were co-constructing this with them. With regard to religious education, they had a significant number of people that have expressed concerns about their approaches towards RE that were set out in the White Paper. There were mixed views on the inclusion of a range of faiths and world religions included in that area of learning. There was also concern about potential challenges with staff in talking about issues that they perhaps personally did not agree with with regard to this curriculum. And also there was much feedback on making sure that the profession was ready to deliver a renewed, modernised RE curriculum.

query: What did Kirsty think of the potential unintended consequences of the curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, the curriculum in itself was neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity, in the sense that the curriculum was what's taught in our schools. What would make the curriculum a success for all of our children, and what would have a bigger impact on children who were in danger of being left behind, were the four enabling purposes of the curriculum. First of all, there was strong leadership of our schools that ensured that there was no segregation, that had high expectation of all of the children. Secondly, excellent teaching. There was an opportunity, I believe, that empowering teachers to be able to be more flexible in what they taught their children actually gave us an opportunity to deliver lessons that could be much more engaging and much more relevant to some of our schoolchildren than what they had at the moment. Thirdly, there were issues around assessment and accountability. There were some issues raised about potential challenges with staff in talking about issues that they perhaps personally did not agree with with regard to this curriculum. Fourthly, it was a balanced paper, it looked at pros and cons and there was a mixed picture from it.

query: What did Kirsty think about the curriculum in itself?
summary: According to Kirsty, the curriculum in itself was neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity, in the sense that the curriculum was what's taught in our schools. What would make the curriculum a success for all of our children, and what would have a bigger impact on children who were in danger of being left behind, were the four enabling purposes of the curriculum. First of all, there would be a statutory framework to ensure that progression was the same wherever you were in Wales. Secondly, teachers were absolutely crucial to this, and they spent a lot of time thinking about accountability and how they were going to be held accountable for their practice. Thirdly, there was an opportunity, I believe, that empowering teachers to be able to be more flexible in what they taught their children actually gave us an opportunity to deliver lessons that could be much more engaging and much more relevant to some of our schoolchildren than what they had at the moment. Fourthly, it was about the connection between Welsh Government and local government and the concerns that the Welsh Local Government Association and the Association of Directors of Education Wales raised.

query: What lessons were being learned from the introduction of their curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, the first thing to realise is that their curriculum was not a copycat of the Scottish curriculum, but it is always useful to reflect on how other systems have undertaken curriculum reform in their nation and to learn from any issues that have arisen. Assessment has been a crucial part of the process that they have been involved in. They have embraced experts who were involved in that process who were part of curriculum assessment group. They feed in throughout the system, not 'don't do this because Scotland has done it', but they feed some of that learning into the system.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the future of the middle tier?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that as they move forward, there would continue to be a focus for each area of learning and experience, bringing together the professional learning and the ongoing curriculum development. They would also bring together practitioners and experts and colleagues across the middle tier to give a bit of strategic direction and to be able to identify if there were areas where more support was needed. They were interested in looking at some of the practices that other countries use to include pupil voice to find out what's happening.

query: What did Kirsty think about the investment in professional learning?
summary: According to Kirsty, it was the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. That money was being made available to each and every school and had empowered headteachers to really think, 'What are the professional needs of my school and the practitioners in my school?' Because, as we've just heard from Claire, there were some schools that had been part of the pioneer process from the very beginning and therefore were further along that development chain. There were other schools that maybe were only beginning now, now that it's published, to be really engaging with the curriculum. So, there's going to clearly be an ongoing programme of preparation development and personal development, as well as anything else.

query: What did Kirsty say about the issue of teachers who were not trained in Wales?
summary: According to Kirsty, they would continue to have a system where teachers trained in Wales would teach in England and teachers trained or who have worked in England would come across the border, as well as teachers from other parts of the world coming to teach in Wales. At a regional level, they require the regions to engage with all schools through the cluster model. They did need a mix of sector—secondary, primary—but also linguistically, to try to make sure that this worked in all the different types of schools. They had not got a monitoring system that said, "Tick every box".

query: What did the group discuss about assessment, progression and accountability?
summary: According to Kirsty, the principles were broadly supported. They received what I would describe as positive feedback regarding the emphasis placed on ongoing assessment that was there to support children's learning and progression. The primary purpose for assessment was for that professional to be able to know how to move that child's educational journey on, and they would absolutely expect professionals to have those conversations with parents to have that conversation about what happens next.

query: How were the general public going to understand the accountability, on both sides of that thick black line?
summary: According to Kirsty, categorisation was never intended to be a way of expressing a league table of school performances; it was there to identify levels of support that a school can expect from its regional consortia. Since coming into office, they had tried to adapt categorisation simply away from pure data to a more formative assessment process, and categorisation would continue to evolve. The message was very clear: this was not to absolve their system of accountability. This was about better accountability, smarter accountability, not less accountability.

query: Why not participate in the PISA?
summary: According to Kirsty, the key factor for making that decision was in 2021 they would be expecting schools to be right in the middle of their preparation for the introduction of the new curriculum, so it was not the right time to do it. The ultimate system that they were going to get to and the ultimate arbiter and the part of the system that provided public assurance and public confidence ultimately ended in Estyn. In terms of creativity, Wales was seen as an exemplar by the OECD, especially our partnership with the Arts Council of Wales and creative learning through the arts. That's why they were not actually going for it and showing how good they were through the PISA.

query: What did the team discuss about getting used to the whiteboard?
summary: Project Manager asked the team to make a new blank new blank page to get used to the whiteboard. User Interface suggested that the team should hold their pens a bit more to the back so that they could write on the paper. Project Manager thought the pens would be just a picture, but User Interface insisted that they actually got to write on that paper.

query: Summarize the discussion about the cost and profit of the universal remote control.
summary: The team agreed that they had to sell the universal remote control for about 25 Euros to make a profit of fifty million Euros. The production cost were about half the price of selling price, so the profit would be about half of the selling price. The product would be made for TV, VCR, DVD player, CD player, etc.

query: What did the group discuss about the functions of the remote control?
summary: Marketing proposed to make the remote control the same style as the television, so that it could be used everywhere in the room. User Interface suggested to make it clear so that kids and elderly could use it, and the infrared thing must be from very good quality. Industrial Designer proposed to put a small touch screen on the remote, but Project Manager thought that it would be too expensive to have a touchscreen on it, so they could make a manual in it instead. And User Interface thought that the remote should not be too big because it had a lot of functions.

query: What did the group think of putting a touchscreen on the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested to put the remote control in a recharger or a home station. Project Manager thought it was not too expensive to put a touchscreen on it, but User Interface thought it would be too expensive. Besides, a touch screen was too fragile and lots of kids used it, so it was better to use normal batteries.

query: What did the group discuss about the functional design of the remote control?
summary: Marketing thought that a home station was a good idea because lots of people lost their remote control and didn't know where it was. However, it would be expensive. Industrial Designer thought that the basic things on the remote control should be put in the same place, like on off button on top and the TV channels one two three four as a block, and the volume obviously on top so that people can see. User Interface thought that buttons that people don't use often should be clear so that they can do something unique with them.

query: What did Project Manager think about folding the remote control when discussing user requirements?
summary: Project Manager thought that it would be hard to make the remote control fold open and look like a fancy one, so he suggested to keep it like a square, just normal remote control. Then he asked the group to think about what kind of buttons they have, what's in the market, what normal buttons are on their remote controls, and what they want to do with it.

query: What did the team discuss about collecting more data?
summary: The team thought that they should collect more data from different kinds of meetings, such as the front-end meeting and the networking group meetings. They also wanted to collect more information from speakers who are not fluent in English. The professor thought that it would be hard to process the data in all senses, both to figure out what type of meeting it was and to do any kind of higher level work on it.

query: What did the professor think about collecting more data?
summary: The professor thought that the team should collect more data from different kinds of meetings to satisfy different interests. He suggested that they could set up a room in the linguistics department or in another building to collect more diverse data. He also suggested using a tape recorder or a found data recorder. He thought that a distant microphone would not be necessary for higher-level tasks.

query: What did the team discuss about the acoustic change in the PDA?
summary: The team discussed how to detect the change, the acoustic change, and the spectral distortion in the PDA. The professor thought that the team should start with the simpler signal because if they have features which don't even help in the high signal-to-noise ratio, then there is no point in putting them into the low signal ratio. The team also discussed whether they should use a speech recognizer or a neural net.

query: What did the Professor think about microphones in the PDAG?
summary: The professor thought that it would be an interesting idea to try to study the binaural problem with microphones in the PDA. He thought that the difference between the speech from different microphones would be interesting to study. The professor also wanted to know whether it was a good idea to use two microphones because it was not necessarily true that every device that they were trying to use would have two microphones. He also thought that there would be a complication if a person turned their back to the microphone and some of the positional information went away.

query: What was said about the transcript?
summary: Transcribers will not be able to change the names of speakers in the transcript. The team discussed how to handle this problem. Postdoc E suggested that they could anonymize the same name for the speaker identifier and also in the text whenever the speaker's name is mentioned.

query: What was said about transcription?
summary: Transcribers will be asked to identify speakers by name, but the team will not be able to do this unless they adopt a consistent licensing policy of some sort.

query: What did the group discuss about the features of the new remote control?
summary: Marketing presented the results of an experiment with a lot of users. The results showed that seventy-five percent of the users found most remote controls ugly, and eighty percent of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy. Older people were more interested in new features, but older people did not like new features because they were more critical about where they spent their money money at. Therefore, the team decided to keep the remote control simple and stand out by just looks of it. The team also decided to make the buttons to choose the next and previous channel, volume, channels, the basic according to, and the on-off button to go to the channel you've been before. Besides, the group agreed to make a basic function like numbers and that sort of stuff to make it a special product.

query: What did the group discuss about the functional design of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested that the remote control should have a light emitting diode producing infrared light, which is invisible to the human eye, and a visible diode that's blinking red if the user looks in it. In order to make it universal, they should make a different shape than usual, so that it stands out from the other remote controls in the shop. In addition, the group agreed to have a recharger in the controller.

query: What did the group discuss about the teletext option of the new remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer explained that teletext had become outdated since the popularity of the internet, so they had to skip that one and make the new product more intelligent. The new product should reach a new market with customers younger than forty, so it should be flashy or just more interesting. Besides, the group agreed to make it more like a mobile phone.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed to put a light under the under the numbers and everything, a simple button on the top, and the more complicated buttons on the bottom. They also agreed to integrate a microphone in the remote control, and to use different colours and fonts for the buttons. They decided to make the buttons in the design very flashy and to integrate the buttons very much. However, they decided not to add speech recognition because they thought it was not useful enough.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the basic design and functional design of the remote control.
summary: The group agreed that the material should be hard plastic, colour changeable, and transparent. The shape of the remote control should be round with round corners and the buttons should be made of hard plastic. The group also agreed to use two D buttons, non-rubber buttons, a num-pad, a scrollwheel, a mute button, a channel button, and a switch channel button. There would be four buttons for speech recognition and a menu button with arrows.

query: What did the group discuss about the buttons on the remote control?
summary: The group agreed to add one button to switch the colour of the LEDs, one button for the zero and one for the more digit channels, a menu button with arrows, one for volume, and one to switch back to normal teletext. There would be one more button for volume. The group also agreed to put the logo for volume on the scroll wheel and some text next to the volume button. The team also decided to add a text button to navigate the menu.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the evaluation criteria of the remote control.
summary: Marketing made some criteria to evaluate the model. The first one was about the fancy look-and-feel of the remote control, like the flashing lights and the background lights from from from the buttons. The second one was the backlight on the slide panel and the switch channel. The group agreed that it was easy to use, but not as fast as a usual remote control. The third criterion was the basic colour of the buttons, which was black and yellow. The team agreed that the buttons could be changed with the switch, so it would be easy to learn.

query: Summarize the discussion about the evaluation of the remote control.
summary: The team agreed that the remote control was easy to use, but the second layer was not easy to learn. The team thought that the speech function and the colour were new, and they could make a front that looked like a banana. Also, the scrollwheel and the slide were pretty new, but they didn't follow the latest trends. Besides, there were no games on it, and it was rechargeable.

query: What did the team discuss about the evaluation of the remote control?
summary: The team agreed that there was room for creativity in the remote control. They could make a different style and use a power indicator to see how far it was charged up. The team also agreed that they got wrong information at the wrong time. However, they were not too hard on themselves because recharge was not on the list.

query: What did the team discuss about the evaluation criteria of the remote control?
summary: The team decided that the fancy look and feel, technological innovation and technological innovation of the remote control should be incorporated into current fashion trends, the material should be spongy and the colour should be fruit and vegetable strong. The team also agreed that the design should minimise RSI and be easy to locate. On the other hand, they were still slightly ambivalent about whether to use voice recognition there, though that did seem to be the favoured strategy, but there was also the idea of maybe having a beeper function.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the appearance of the remote control when discussing the evaluation criteria?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the base colour of the remote control would be white or light blue and the material would be hard plastic. However, the changeable faces would allow users to get any strong fruit and vegetable colours and that's what they were intending to do. The remote control incorporated current fashion trends and was easy to locate.

query: What did the team discuss about the kinetic cell design of the remote control?
summary: Marketing thought that the team had not really come up with anything that could feasibly reduce the number of kinetic cells on the remote control. However, the team agreed that the type of button that they were going to use in the bottom half, the material, and the easy to locate were all good features. The team also agreed that it would be quite loud and easy to find.

query: What did the team decide to do to reduce the cost of certain components?
summary: Industrial Designer proposed to change the chip to one and one sample sensor and sample speaker to double-curved. User Interface suggested that they could change the battery to a standard one. However, Project Manager pointed out that they were using a very low quantity of rubber compared to plastic, so they could not incorporate the cost of the rubber in the total cost.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the product cost.
summary: The group agreed that they were close to the budget and that they could offer the voice recognition initially to business class customers because they had done all the background work to go for that if they wanted it. They also agreed that the object of the remote control should be distinctive so that it would make it easier to locate in a first instance.

query: What did the team discuss about the product evaluation?
summary: Marketing thought that the team had done a great job in bringing new ideas in general and applying it to a different area. However, Project Manager pointed out that no one had put a great deal of thought into the design of the flip top because the company was focused on the product they were trying to ship, which was the DVD player, video player, the TV, and the heating for the building. Industrial Designer thought that they had done very well to get within budget, but they had still got all of the overheads to come out of that, so they would have to increase the price that it's sold at.

query: What did the group discuss about the additional learning needs sector?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked whether the additional learning needs sector was adversely affected by the new Act coming into force, and whether it was going to place more pressure on the system. Sharon Davies was not sure whether it's being adversely affected, but certainly there's pressure. The delegation levels were already very high in most authority areas, and they had got agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money, or as much money as possible, was devolved to schools. However, there were financial pressures there, but they did not think the levels of delegation have any impact on that.

query: What more can be done to support collaborative working between schools, PRUs and local authorities to ensure that there is a continuum of provision and support for learners?
summary: According to Nick Williams, one of the things that has improved a lot is the networking within the PRU sector. The delegation levels are already very high in most authority areas, and they've got agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money, or as much money as possible, is devolved to schools. But in the past, there might well have been some staff who perhaps hadn't had those school experiences and vice versa. So, there's definitely a better sharing of practice. Also, in fairness to PRUs, they've been trying to work on the fact that, if children move out of school, the funding follows them.

query: What are the reasons for the delays that some children experience in accessing EOTAS?
summary: According to Nick, at least one authority is looking at how they can best retain all pupils in the school setting, but it's early days yet for looking at that. query: What did Dr Ian Johnson think of the issue of transport for EOTAS learners?

query: What did Dr Ian Johnson and Dr. Ian Johnson think about the increase in the number of children being excluded from school?

query: What did Dr Ian Johnson think about the number of young people who were home schooled?

query: What did the team discuss about the video code at the end of programme details?
summary: Project Manager mentioned that the video code at the end of programme details could be used as an alternative to programming in times when people were not sure if they were going to watch a particular program. The team agreed that it would be a good idea to include this function in the remote control. However, the team was not sure how much the cost would be of having this function.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the design of the remote control.
summary: The group agreed that the remote control should not be big with lots of buttons and be as user-friendly as possible. They also agreed to get away from the brown rectangles with the same coloured buttons all crammed in on the surface and to use a rechargeable battery instead. The group also discussed the design of the flip-screen and the company logo.

query: What did Project Manager say about the new project requirements?
summary: Project Manager explained that the new project requirements were no teletext, it was only for TV and by implication video, their corporate image should be incorporated in the remote control, and the company logo should be included in the design of the product so that it would be different from anything else in the market. Also, there would be a beeping alarm or something for being lost, a reminder about using Videoplus, and rechargeable batteries for detection. The group agreed to work through the new requirements and choose which appeals the most like.

query: Summarize the discussion on segmentation
summary: The team thought that the PLP was improving and that they should move to doing the recognition on automatic segmentations. The experiment with the vocal tract length normalization was working well and they could train noise models in the recognizer for these kinds of transients and things that came from the microphones.

query: What’s the status of transcription?
summary: Transcribers have continued to work past set one and are in the process of being edited. They have hired two more transcribers and are thinking of hiring another one. The team is hoping that the IBM hiring will help them get into production mode.

query: Summarize the progress on meeting transcription
summary: Transcribers have transcribed sixty-two hours of meetings so far and are in the process of being edited. The team is planning to keep the staff on the leaner side rather than hiring more than eight to ten, but they should have a plan for what they will do with the data by July.

query: What did the team discuss about the classifier?
summary: The team thought that some of the features that were showing up in the classifier were cheating, like the distance of the boundaries from peaks in the utterance and some local pitch range effects, like how close people were to their floor. The team also thought that the pitch features were better than in Switchboard because the pitch processing was cleaner and there was a lot less dropout.

query: Summarize the discussion on the pitch features and speaker effects
summary: The team thought that the pitch features were better in the close-talking mikes than in Switchboard because the pitch processing was done with much cleaner behavior. The team was also getting better signals in the data, which was a good sign. However, the team was concerned that the model was not generalizing well due to the large speaker effects. The professor explained that the team had tried changing the insertion penalties, but it didn't help much.

query: What did the Professor think about the model?
summary: The professor informed the team that there were two problems with the model. One was a big DC offset. The other was that the RASTA filter was doing a different thing in the modulation spectral domain depending on what sampling rate they were doing. The professor thought that it was more important to not take a lot of low-variance components.

query: What did the professor say about the Mississippi State recognizer?
summary: The professor informed the team that the team had started working on the Mississippi State recognizer and that they had tried including the full full bank of data from zero to four K. The team thought that a lot of the noise was below a hundred hertz, so they needed to take account of this. The professor also informed them that they were experimenting with noise-processing techniques.

query: What did PhD C think about the Mississippi State recognizer?
summary: PhD C informed the team that he had started working on the Mississippi State recognizer. He had downloaded the software and compiled all of the parameters. The model was running on nine frames of six features from C-zero to C-five, plus the first derivatives. There was also a delta at the input and a hundred hidden units. The team thought that the model was performing well, but the latency was too large.

query: What did the professor think about noise compensation?
summary: The professor thought that the noise compensation process was imperfect. He thought that it was better to have the neural net with pure features than with the pure features.

query: What did the professor think about LDA?
summary: The professor thought that the LDA was a great idea. He thought that it would be a good idea to try LDA without neural nets because it would allow the model to learn to distinguish between different types of features without having to deal with the high cost frequency. He also thought that LDA would be better than LDA with neural nets.

query: What did PhD D think about VAD latency?
summary: PhD D explained that the team had been exploring a parallel VAD without neural net with less latency using SNR and energy after the cleaning up. The team thought that the delay was due to the fact that the silence probability was too high. PhD D also wanted to know if the neural net was able to distinguish between speech and nonspeech.

query: What did the Professor think about silence?
summary: The professor thought that the silence probability was too high. He wanted to know if it was due to the fact that the probability of silence at the output of the network was high. The team thought that they could look at the distribution of the output and see if there were more peaks. The professor also suggested that the team could run the model on different test sets, including large vocabulary.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the components design.
summary: Marketing suggested that the first thing to aim for is a fancy look and feel, followed by the technologic technology and the innovations to do with that. Then, the group discussed whether to use rubber, plastic, wood or titanium, and whether to print the fruit stuff or should the actual remote look like a fruit. Finally, they discussed the material of the remote control and whether it should be printed or not.

query: What did the group discuss about the wheel design of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the wheel could go through a hundred channels. User Interface thought it would be better if the wheel only had a long silver thing and no buttons other than the power and the menu button. Project Manager agreed and suggested that the remote control should be comfortable to use.

query: What did the group discuss about the menu button and the touch-based graphical interface?
summary: Industrial Designer believed that the menu button should be inside the TV, not inside the remote. Project Manager thought that it was technologically innovative in a way. User Interface thought that the touch-based graphical interface was a cool idea.

query: What did the group discuss about the cover material of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that people wanted the remote control to be spongy because they wanted it to look like a banana, but Project Manager didn't like the idea of a stress ball material because he thought it was not comfortable to hold. Marketing suggested that they could use a cover made of rubber and the colour could be named after fruits and vegetables. Project Manager agreed and suggested that the cover could be made of silver because those were their company colours.

query: What did the group discuss about changing the hard part of the remote control into a squashy ball?
summary: Marketing proposed to change the hard part of the remote control into a squashy ball, but the project manager rejected this idea because he thought it was not very neat. Industrial Designer proposed to make it into a single ball shape, but this idea was rejected by the group because it would be hard to change. Project Manager then proposed to use a cover for the squashy bit, which was cheaper, and to ask users what the best was. The group agreed to do two prototypes and see what the cost was for covering that or covering the cover.

query: What did Industrial Designer introduce about energy sources?
summary: Industrial Designer first introduced the three options of batteries, solar power, and a dynamo. Solar power was not available with the rubber case and solar power was a little weird for a living room anyways. The other two options were a wind-up or a kinetic thing where you'd basically have to wind it yourself and the dynamo was a bicycle mechanism. The dynamo would be interesting because the moment it was moved, it created energy on its own and users didn't need to buy a battery.

query: Summarize the discussion about market trends.
summary: Industrial Designer presented the findings of the market trends. The most important aspect for remote controls was fancy look and feel, followed by being technologically innovative and easy to use. In terms of material, there was a trend towards a spongy feel to materials, which was in contrast to last year. The team also discussed the availability of the components and battery options.

query: What did Industrial Designer think of the kinetic battery when discussing the battery life?
summary: Industrial Designer explained that the kinetic battery would charge into some form of a smaller cell which it charges into and the battery would last for a long time. However, Project Manager questioned whether it would be enough since the watch was always moving for the whole day and they didn't run out over night when they left them on the side. Industrial Designer argued that the amount the user would be doing all the time would charge it up, so he didn't think they would need to actually physically start shaking it up to make it work.

query: What did the team think about the solar cells and the batteries when discussing the functional design of the remote?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the solar cells would not be very resistant to dropping because they were quite big and the batteries were smaller. Project Manager thought that it would detract from the attractiveness of the whole feature because remotes always get thrown around and stuff, so they had to look at the life also.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about case material when discussing the design of the remote?
summary: Industrial Designer firstly pointed out that most current remotes use a silicone P-C-B board which basically has these contacts that are really close together and then when you press down on the rubber button, it will connect the circuit and each switch is connected to two different legs on the chip and so sends a different message and that then gets translated by the chip into a code and then it is fired out in the sequence of on and off bursts. The main problems with the case material are that it is expensive just to process and it would have to fit the design of

query: What did Industrial Designer suggest about the interface designs with the buttons when discussing the basic mould and the rubber cover of the phone?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested that they could make the basic mould out of plastic but have a rubber cover that goes over, which would give the spongy feel and allow them to kind of have different fasciae for the phone. However, the problem with the rubber cover was that it was flat and so they couldn't do lots of curve curved things with it. Industrial Designer also suggested that the buttons could be arranged in a sort of array and the buttons on the screen could be like a touch.

query: What did the group discuss about the circuit design of the flip-top?
summary: Industrial Designer proposed that they could keep the standard buttons on the top and the more complex buttons under the thing, and they could customise the two circuits for different type of buttons. However, Project Manager thought it would be good to have a contrast between the rubber buttons which were made of this material which was anti-RSI and the conventional buttons which are made of ordinary rubber. Marketing also raised an objection to the idea of a touch-pad because he thought it might be irritating for people who switched channels very often or did use a particular function very often and it might spoil the touch pad very fast compared to a button if they kept punching with an pointer or whatever.

query: What did the team decide to do about the flip-top shell when discussing the functional design of the remote?
summary: Marketing suggested that the flip-top shell could be a little compact mirror and when users pressed a button, it would go onto the phone display. However, Project Manager rejected the idea because it would be inconvenient for users to hold it in the palm of their hand. Also, Industrial Designer pointed out that the full charge through an LCD display would completely blank it out, so the team decided to leave the mirror on the side.

query: What did the team discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: The team agreed that the design should be inspired from fruit colours, like the vibrant colours, red chilli and tomato red, and certain standard buttons should have, like volume and channel. Also, voice recognition should be standardised because it was the most common feature across all models and it would be cheap to re-manufacture them.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about kinetic charging when discussing the energy source?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that kinetic charging was a good idea because it would be cheap to re-manufacture the remote control. However, Project Manager pointed out that double A or triple A batteries would be a back-up so they had to cut down somewhere else.

query: What would the rubberised cover look like when discussing the design of the remote control?
summary: The rubberised cover would be made of plastic and rubberised and spongy. It would be in vegetable and fruit colours. The team would choose from a variety of designs such as red, psychedelic, psychedelic stripes, black and white zebra stripes, sparkly pink glittery ones, etc. The rubberised covers would be relatively cheap to produce and would be easy to slip on. The remote control would be different from other remotes in the market because it would have a fancy look and feel.

query: What did the team discuss about the functional design of the remote control?
summary: The team decided to use watch-type batteries, LCD display on the top side of the flip top, rubberised buttons on the bottom side, fruit and vegetable colours for the rubber cover, the case itself is plastic, and the whistle would be incorporated in the design. They also decided to incorporate the company logo and voice recognition into the design of the remote control.

query: Summarize the discussion about Industrial Designer's presentation on the implementation of things.
summary: Industrial Designer presented some initial ideas about the implementation of things, the technical possibilities and the impossibilities. He also reminded people of some new technical possibilities which were available and which might be interesting to implement in the product.

query: What did the group discuss about the inter-operability of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that one remote control should control one or more pieces of equipment, and the way of communicating with these equipments should fit to every device. User Interface thought that a universal remote control for customers to buy just new in a store should be something like that.

query: What did User Interface think about the technical function of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the remote control should change the TV's state by pressing the button. User Interface thought that infrared should be restricted to the TV.

query: What did User Interface think about the range of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested that infrared might be an issue for remote control, but User Interface disagreed. For TV, users were always in the neighbourhood of a TV, so the range should not be a problem to that. However, if remote control was to work with a radio, and people were in outside their garden with just one speaker, then the range might be limited. User Interface also suggested that users should be able to feel the buttons without looking at the buttons, and that all buttons should be visible in dark.

query: What did the group discuss about the market response to the remote control?
summary: Marketing suggested that infrared might be an issue because lots of devices already use infrared, so they would probably have to implement that. User Interface suggested that a display on the remote control would make it easier for users to see functions. Industrial Designer suggested that the digits of the buttons should be painted in black so that they would not fade in the dark. Project Manager agreed and added that the device should be rechargeable very easily.

query: What did the group discuss about Bluetooth?
summary: Industrial Designer thought Bluetooth might be a problem because it was use a lot of time. Project Manager thought cell phones had integrated Bluetooth also and it seemed to work quite okay. So they could only light the buttons that were applicable at that moment or only use Bluetooth all the time, twenty four hours a day.
